op.name: BSO
op.title: [[ Broken Sky Online Quest - Session 8 ]]
op.comment:
> [[ Broken Sky Online ]]
> [[ Previous Threads ]]
http://suptg.thisisnotatrueending.com/archive.html?tags=Broken%20Sky
> [[ Unique Identifier: Ascheritte ]]
http://pastebin.com/pZv3XUPQ
> [[ Twitter ]]
https://twitter.com/BrokenSkyOnline

With the help of Eunoia, as well as some of the bandages you found, you manage to restore your health to your new maximum. You stand up and dust yourself off, vision returning to normal, with the rest of your party standing by. Liza's also nearby, messaging someone on her UI; you're not sure who it could be, but given the scenario, it's probably one of the Alliance higher-ups.

“Fuck,” She shakes her head. “How am I going to explain this?”

“You could start by helping with the rioting.” Donnel says. “Things weren't looking too good last I checked.”

“I've had my guild regroup.” Liza responds. “Most of the larger Nameless groups have been routed, according to Andor. The market square will take some time to recover, but the guild halls and the city square are mostly clear.”

“Mostly?” Nel asks. “Sounds like there's still some tension.”

“Travel in groups.” Liza says, Crimson Wings unfolding on her back with a series of high-pitched mechanical chirps. “The biggest problem has been ambush attacks. I'm going to make a sweep before I get back to the Guardians' hall.”

“I'd tell you to be careful, but...” Aelriss winces, glancing briefly at the number of dead Nameless scattering the room. “You seem like you're doing a fine job already.”

A fine job? You sigh. You'd like to tell Liza off, but you're in no position to. And on the other hand, she was uninformed. Hell, you might have done the same thing.

“I'm trying.” Liza turns, and there's a faint whine of her Artifact warming up. “I've got to go.”

> Ask Liza about joining the Guardians.
> Ask Liza something else. (Write-in.)
> Let Liza go, and figure out what to do next.
> Let Liza go, but tell Ayla about her deception.

38116326.name: BSO
38116326.comment:
>>38115464

“Liza.” You ask. “Now's not the best time, but I'd like to talk to you later about joining the Guardians.”

“Mm...” She raises an eyebrow. “If you're really interested, then come by our hall later. After all of the action around Averron gets sorted out. I'll be online for a while, and someone will talk to you if not.”

“Alright,” You respond. “Thanks.”

She steps outside and launches skyward out of view.

“Aw, Ashe.” Nel frowns. “You're really thinking about joining up with them?”

“Just thinking about it.” You respond. “It'd be nice to be in one of the top guilds.”

“Makes sense to me.” Donnel says. “I would, if I thought I'd fit in.”

There's a pause. “Alright, then.” You say, leading the group out of the warehouse. “What do you guys want to do now?”

“I was hoping we'd be able to get to the market square.” Nel says. “I think we've all got stuff we need to do there. After that, I think I'm going to log out. It's been a bit of a day.”

“Mhm.” Donnel responds. “I've got stuff to try and sell, and I want to see if I can get anything crafted before I think about burning off myself.”

“You know anyone that can do that?” Aelriss asks. “I've been looking for a trustworthy crafter. Or a good Technician...”

“Nope,” He says. “NPCs are fine for smaller stuff, though. If you find somebody, let me know.”

Tatsumaki pensively fumbles about in her UI menu briefly before producing an item: the Earthen Orb, and offering it to Aelriss.

“Huh? This is an elemental focus.” She asks. “You want me to use this?”

> Head to the market square as a group.
> Offer to split up, and head back to the tavern.
> Offer to split up, and head back to the city center.
> Offer to split up, and head back to the fortune teller.

“If we're going to the market square, let's stick together.” You respond. “Could still be dangerous.”

“Agreed.” Donnel says. “Alright, how long are we gonna stand here?”

The five of you make your way out of the warehouse and into the street, weapons ready. Some distance away, a group of Nameless gathered under a wrought-iron lamppost watch you, quietly. You keep your eyes on them, hand eased on the hilt of the greatsword at your back.

If it came to a fight, there's no doubt in your mind your group would win. They don't act, and you pass further into the city without event. You'd hate to advocate further violence within the city; hell, you might even make enemies among the Alliance were you the ones who started further fighting.

It's a lot quieter now. Remaining in a tight group, the five of you make your way into the market square. A number of the player-run stalls are damaged, derelict, or destroyed now, though there's a few that are still manned. Altogether, it looks like people are tallying the losses.

You can see the general store where the NPC crafters and salesmen are located. Further down the street, you can see the tavern. The building looks like it's sustained heavy fire damage; the cozy interior appearance apparently comes at the cost of durability. There's a number of people gathered outside, and small groups file in and out.

“I'm heading to the general store.” Donnel says. “Gotta get some crafting done.”

“Same. I need to restock.” Nel responds. “Maybe I can do something with this chain, too.”

“Tatsumaki and I will be out here window-shopping, then.” Aelriss says. “Careful, you guys.”

You head to the general store, looping past the counter and the groups of loitering players to the blacksmith's corner. Your steps make clanking noises as you enter this room; there's a pronounced hollowness to the rusty metal floor beneath you, and a vague scent of smoke.

There's a few players walking from wall to wall, inspecting the various weapons on display. Nearby, you see an NPC. He's larger than most of the ones you've seen, clad in a bright red greatcoat; he's got a flat, feathered face, with an oddly serpentine tail. Currently, he's working some sort of high-tech looking forge, that levitates and shapes heated ingots with the help of small tools and minor hand movements; there's various shelves behind him of leather straps, metal bits, and crystals.

“Aye?” He looks up as you approach. “What can I do for you?”

“Can you reforge a, uhm. 'pegasus gilded mail'?” You ask.

“Ah, an interesting type of armor.” He says. “It augments the inertia of its wearers, but it's no good if you're too heavy to get moving.”

38117508.name: BSO
38117508.comment:
>>38117210

You have the blacksmith create a Pegasus Cuirass, costing 160# after you trade in your current patched leather armor as well as the mining pick. It's golden, like the horse's harness, with light pauldrons that sit right over your shoulders. Parts in the frame around your chest are filled in by a sturdy iron chain-mail. It fits perfectly, and looks excellent.

You feel tougher.

“What about onyx?” You ask. He doesn't seem to know what you mean, until you present the shards in your inventory.

“Those types of weapons are best used for slashing or piercing, and they make good arrowheads if you prefer primitive ranged weapons.” He responds. “Their durability is low overall, and they're too heavy to make proper armor with. You can do the most damage against unarmored targets. Against proper armor, your blows might not cut so deep.”

“What can I do with this fractalline crystal?” You ask.

“They're essential parts of all casters.” He responds. “They come in a lot of rare varieties, and are often hard to find unless you mine them.”

“What can I do with this fractalline crystal?” You ask.

“They're essential parts of all casters.” He responds. “They come in a lot of rare varieties, and are often hard to find unless you mine them.”

> Write-in.
> Return to the market square.
> Sell other weapons or armor.
> Search for another weapon to buy.

38120292.name: BSO
38120292.comment:
>>38119653

"This ability, the unknown one." You begin to ask about the unknown ability you have, but aren't sure how to vocalize it. You're having a strange feeling, like you've gone through motions identical to these before. You use your UI to project your skill menu onto the table, and point at it for the fortune teller.

"Mm, yes."

The NPC appears as if they're beginning to speak; then, their animations abruptly reset with a noticeable twitch. This time, they open their mouth, and cough up a terrible hissing that lasts less than a second. Your ears hurt.

Another razor-toothed smile, as the animation replays, and those eyes look at you with purpose and intensity.

"It seems someone is playing games with you.”

"What?" You ask; the response is unfamiliar, but they quickly slip back into their usual phrases.

"Strange, that you would fancy this meeting when our futures are so murky." 

"One can see many things in the ether, and learn more from the Celestials. Uncover their artifacts by searching carefully in your travels through dangerous locations, and you will find the truth in a matter of time." They tilt their head. You remember this speech. They're right. There's a burning in the back of your mind. All you need to do is find more Celestial Gems. God, how could you have been so stupid? 

"My sight is much vaster than many. Clear your mind, child, and allow me to alleviate your worries. Where shall I direct my gaze?" 

“I need to know about Velika and Kjorikos.” You step forward, planting your hands on the table. The thought occurs to you, and you produce the dusty memento, whirling it around to face the NPC. You remember the face of the woman, Velika, beautiful though haunting. “The woman in this portrait.”

“Child, there is no woman in that portrait.”

> [[ Continued ]]

The fortune-teller cackles. You turn it back around. They're right. It's an empty frame with a carefully-painted washed out tomb-wall. Spiderweb cracks in the concrete crawl downward, giving way to a shade of red the color of fresh blood. “I feel a malefic gaze upon you. Have you done something you might regret?”

“What can you tell me about them?” You shout.

“Kjorikos was a brilliant artificer of old, who first harnessed the power of elements with aetheric technology. He gave the world much, but was condemned as heretical for his practices. In time, he fell to dark, for nothing he tried could bring back the one he loved most.” The fortune-teller says. “He buried her, and built his sanctum upon her tomb.”

What will you do?
